pullRequest.body:
This PR introduces the binomial series (as `FormalMultilinearSeries`) for an algebra over a field of characteristic zero.  
#### Main Results:
- `binomialSeries_radius_ge_one`: The radius of convergence of the binomial series is at least 1.
- `one_add_rpow_hasFPowerSeriesAt_zero`: For real `a` and `|x| < 1`, the binomial series `âˆ‘ k, (Ring.choose a k) * x^k` converges to `(1 + x).rpow a`. Here I use [this](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binomial_series#Summation_of_the_binomial_series) proof in which one shows that the series and the `(1 + x)^a` function satisfy the same ODE. 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->
- [ ] depends on: #19816
- [ ] depends on: #19848

I added the `Mathlib.Tactic.MoveAdd` import to `noshake`, as it attempts to remove this import even though it is required for the `move_mul` tactic.

This PR is necessary for my tactic (#18486), which computes the asymptotics of real functions, where I use the binomial series to approximate real powers of functions.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#19816~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#19848~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

### PR summary [ec28fc188e](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20011/commits/ec28fc188e7637553ea7165d64273d23bf2d82a5)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.RingTheory.Binomial | 1017 | 1020 | +3 (+0.29%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.LaurentSeries`|1|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.Binomial`|3|
| `Mathlib.Analysis.Analytic.Binomial` (new file)|1883|

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ ascPochhammer_smeval_nonneg`
`+ binomialSeries`
`+ binomialSeries_ODE`
`+ binomialSeries_radius_ge_one`
`+ choose_eq_smul`
`+ descPochhammer_le_ascPochhammer`
`+ one_add_rpow_hasFPowerSeriesAt_zero`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Thanks for pointing me to the API, I should have found it myself. The proof actually consists of two parts:  

1. Proving that the series converges.  
2. Proving that the series satisfies the same ODE as `(1 + x)^a`.  

It seems I can simply use the existing API to prove the first part and keep the second part as is.

I hate to say this, but I think this should be implemented completely differently. In particular, I think it should be implemented as a [ordinaryHypergeometricSeries](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/SpecialFunctions/OrdinaryHypergeometric.html#ordinaryHypergeometricSeries), maybe as an abbreviation even. Then the radius computation will come for free from [ordinaryHypergeometricSeries_radius_eq_one](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/SpecialFunctions/OrdinaryHypergeometric.html#ordinaryHypergeometricSeries_radius_eq_one), or from [ordinaryHypergeometric_radius_top_of_neg_natâ‚](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/SpecialFunctions/OrdinaryHypergeometric.html#ordinaryHypergeometric_radius_top_of_neg_nat%E2%82%81) in the case when the exponent is a natural number. This gives you access to that API too as a result.

Do you want to try reimplementing it with that technique?

I hate to say this, but I think this should be implemented completely differently. In particular, I think it should be implemented as a [ordinaryHypergeometricSeries](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/SpecialFunctions/OrdinaryHypergeometric.html#ordinaryHypergeometricSeries), maybe as an abbreviation even. Then the radius computation will come for free from [ordinaryHypergeometricSeries_radius_eq_one](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/SpecialFunctions/OrdinaryHypergeometric.html#ordinaryHypergeometricSeries_radius_eq_one), or from [ordinaryHypergeometric_radius_top_of_neg_natâ‚](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/SpecialFunctions/OrdinaryHypergeometric.html#ordinaryHypergeometric_radius_top_of_neg_nat%E2%82%81) in the case when the exponent is a natural number. This gives you access to that API too as a result.

Do you want to try reimplementing it with that technique?

This looks very nice!  However, I would like to use this series outside the `NormedField` context.  Could we have something like:
```
noncomputable def PowerSeries.binomialSeries {R : Type v} [Ring R] [BinomialRing R] {A : Type u} [One A] [SMul R A] (r : R) :
    PowerSeries A :=
  mk fun n => (Ring.choose r n) â€¢ (1 : A)
```
and turn it into a `FormalMultilinearSeries` later?

Thank you! I'm not sure about this. I'm not very familiar with the `PowerSeries` API. It seems there isn't an easy way to convert a `PowerSeries` to a `FormalMultilinearSeries` so far. This should probably be done in a separate PR.

pullRequest.title: feat(Analysis): binomial series convergence
